docs.lead_paragraph: Advocates and opponents of “open access” for government-financed scientific research are girding for a long battle before Congress, which has little enthusiasm for either extreme.

headline.seo: A Wide Gulf on Open Access to Federally Financed Research
headline.main: Gulf on Open Access to Federally Financed Research
headline.print_headline: Gulf on Open Access to Federally Financed Research

docs.abstract: Advocates and opponents of 'open access' for government-financed scientific research are girding for a long battle before Congress, which has little enthusiasm for either extreme; Obama administration's Office of Science and Technology Policy will submit to Congress a progress report on its search for a balanced approach.
docs.snippet: Advocates and opponents of “open access” for government-financed scientific research are girding for a long battle before Congress, which has little enthusiasm for either extreme.

keywords.value: Office of Science and Technology Policy
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers in Big Sur-Monterey are trying to determine why, despite decades of efforts, the population is barely growing. Some blame pollutants, others a decline in food.

headline.seo: Sea Otters’ Failure to Thrive Confounds Researchers
headline.main: Pacific Sea Otters’ Failure to Thrive Confounds Wildlife Sleuths
headline.print_headline: Pacific Sea Otters’ Failure to Thrive Confounds Wildlife Sleuths

docs.abstract: Wildlife biologists in Monterey Bay area of California are trying to determine why, despite decades of efforts, the region's population of sea otters is barely growing; theories include the proliferation of pollutants and a decline in food supply.
docs.snippet: Researchers in Big Sur-Monterey are trying to determine why, despite decades of efforts, the population is barely growing. Some blame pollutants, others a decline in food.

docs.lead_paragraph: During flu season in Bangladesh, mothers who got shots in their last trimester gave birth to babies almost seven ounces heavier on average.

headline.seo: Flu Shots for Expectant Mothers Add to Babies’ Birth Weight
headline.main: Flu: Flu Shots for Expectant Mothers Add to Babies’ Birth Weight
headline.print_headline: Flu: Vaccines for Women in the Last Trimester Add to Babies’ Birth Weight in Bangladesh

docs.abstract: Dr Mark C Steinhoff study in The Canadian Medical Association Journal finds that third-trimester flu shots given to pregnant women in Bangladesh appeared to increase the birth weights of their babies, making infants' survival more likely.
docs.snippet: During flu season in Bangladesh, mothers who got shots in their last trimester gave birth to babies almost seven ounces heavier on average.

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists had known of DNA since 1869, but The New York Times did not mention it until 78 years later.
docs.abstract: The New York Times first mentioned DNA in an article on July 1, 1947.
docs.snippet: Scientists had known of DNA since 1869, but The New York Times did not mention it until 78 years later.

docs.lead_paragraph: The common practice of inserting a stent to repair a narrowed artery has no benefit over standard medical care in treating stable coronary artery disease.

headline.seo: Stents Show No Extra Benefits for Coronary Artery Disease
headline.main: No Extra Benefits Are Seen in Stents for Coronary Artery Disease
headline.print_headline: No Extra Benefits Are Seen in Stents for Coronary Artery Disease

docs.abstract: Dr David L Brown review of randomized controlled cardiac trials published in The Archives of Internal Medicine finds the common practice of inserting a stent to repair a narrowed artery has no benefit over standard medical care in treating stable coronary artery disease; Brown suggests that favored use of stents over medications may have a financial motivation.
docs.snippet: The common practice of inserting a stent to repair a narrowed artery has no benefit over standard medical care in treating stable coronary artery disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: A study of older adults finds that those with higher omega-3 fatty acid levels had larger brain volume and performed better in tests of mental acuity.

headline.seo: Omega-3 Fatty Acid Levels Linked to Brain Performance
headline.main: Nutrition: Brainpower Tied to Omega-3 Levels
headline.print_headline: Nutrition: Brainpower Tied to Omega-3 Levels

docs.abstract: Dr Zaldy S Tan publishes study in journal Neurology finding that low blood levels of omega-3 fatty acids are associated with smaller brain volume and poorer performance on tests of mental acuity, even in people without apparent dementia.
docs.snippet: A study of older adults finds that those with higher omega-3 fatty acid levels had larger brain volume and performed better in tests of mental acuity.

docs.lead_paragraph: If 100 people are exposed to cold germs, 50 to 80, in whom resistance is compromised for any of a variety of reasons, would be expected to get sick.
docs.abstract: Science Q&A on factors affecting the contagiousness of a cold.
docs.snippet: If 100 people are exposed to cold germs, 50 to 80, in whom resistance is compromised for any of a variety of reasons, would be expected to get sick.

docs.lead_paragraph: Since the baby boomers discovered yoga, the arousal, sweating, heavy breathing and states of undress that characterize yoga classes have led to predictable results.

headline.seo: Yoga Fans Sexual Flames and, Predictably, Plenty of Scandal
headline.main: Yoga and Sex Scandals: No Surprise Here
headline.print_headline: Yoga and Sex Scandals: No Surprise Here

docs.abstract: Many followers of John Friend, founder of fast-growing Yoga technique Anusara, are discouraged after learning that he has been accused of sexual impropriety with a number of female students; Friend's fall from grace is emblematic of the sexually-charged nature of Yoga, which began as a Tantric practice, and has often been associated with sexual scandal; some researchers are beginning to understand the physiological underpinnings of how Yoga leads to arousal.
docs.snippet: Since the baby boomers discovered yoga, the arousal, sweating, heavy breathing and states of undress that characterize yoga classes have led to predictable results.
